problem:
Suppose that $\{a_n\}_{n \geq 0}$ is a non-negative sequence satisfying
$$
a_{m+n} \leq a_m + a_n + C
$$
for all positive integers $m, n$ and some non-negative constant $C$. Show that $a_n / n$ converges as $n \to \infty$.
solution:
For an arbitrary fixed positive integer $k$ we put $n = qk + r$ with $0 \leq r < k$. Since $a_n = a_{qk+r} \leq q(a_k + C) + a_r$, we have
$$
\frac{a_n}{n} \leq \frac{a_k + C}{k} + \frac{a_r}{n}.
$$
Taking the limit as $n \to \infty$, we get
$$
\limsup_{n \to \infty} \frac{a_n}{n} \leq \frac{a_k + C}{k}.
$$
The sequence $a_n / n$ is therefore bounded. Since $k$ is arbitrary, we may conclude that
$$
\limsup_{n \to \infty} \frac{a_n}{n} \leq \liminf_{k \to \infty} \frac{a_k}{k},
$$
which means the convergence of $a_n / n$.
